doc_content.text: Gold wastage during creation of ornaments can't be treated as 'making charges'; Sec. 194C TDS not applicable

doc_content.text: Facts  of  the  case  -  P.R.  Gold  and  Silver  Craft  v.  DCIT  -  [2022] (Chennai - Trib.)

metadata.orig_text: Facts  of  the  case  -  P.R.  Gold  and  Silver  Craft  v.  DCIT  -  [2022] (Chennai - Trib.)

doc_content.text: Assessee was engaged in the business of making gold and silver jewellery. During the relevant year, assessee purchased old jewellery from the customers and the same was melted by the goldsmiths to get pure gold.

metadata.orig_text: Assessee was engaged in the business of making gold and silver jewellery. During the relevant year, assessee purchased old jewellery from the customers and the same was melted by the goldsmiths to get pure gold.

doc_content.text: During the process of making new ornaments, some gold suffered wastage which was retained by the goldsmiths. During the relevant year, the assessee claimed to have incurred wastages from 5%- 6%.

metadata.orig_text: During the process of making new ornaments, some gold suffered wastage which was retained by the goldsmiths. During the relevant year, the assessee claimed to have incurred wastages from 5%- 6%.

doc_content.text: However,  the  Assessing  Officer  restricted  the  wastage  percentage  to  1%  and contended that the wastage over 1% was to be treated as making charges. AO held that the assessee failed to deduct tax under section 194C on these making charges and made disallowance under section 40(a)(ia).

doc_content.text: On appeal, the CIT(A) confirmed the action of AO. Aggrieved-assessee filed the instant appeal before the Tribunal.

metadata.orig_text: On appeal, the CIT(A) confirmed the action of AO. Aggrieved-assessee filed the instant appeal before the Tribunal.

doc_content.text:  The Tribunal held that the manufacturing of ornaments involves various processes  and  the  wastage  is  actual  and  real.  However,  the  given  case didn't pertain to the eligibility of wastage but pertained to whether such wastage was liable to deduction of tax under section 194C.

metadata.orig_text:  The Tribunal held that the manufacturing of ornaments involves various processes  and  the  wastage  is  actual  and  real.  However,  the  given  case didn't pertain to the eligibility of wastage but pertained to whether such wastage was liable to deduction of tax under section 194C.

doc_content.text:  The entire process of the assessee was it had outsourced its manufacturing to  certain  jewelers  outside  Pondicherry  and  pathars  in  Pondicherry.  The jewelers  had  not  claimed  any  wastage  as  loss  as  they  paid  higher  job charges which includes the value of wastage suffered. However, the pathars claimed wastage but paid lessor job charges.

doc_content.text:  The assessee filed party-wise details of the making charges paid to jewellers and pathars and details of tax deducted therefrom.

doc_content.text:  It should be noted that the provisions of section 194C are applicable when the assessee has paid or credited any charges covered thereunder. In case, no payment is debited or credited to the respective party's account, then such payment cannot be considered within the ambit of section 194C or any other TDS provisions.

metadata.orig_text:  It should be noted that the provisions of section 194C are applicable when the assessee has paid or credited any charges covered thereunder. In case, no payment is debited or credited to the respective party's account, then such payment cannot be considered within the ambit of section 194C or any other TDS provisions.

doc_content.text:  In the given case, the claim of wastage whether it is 1% or 6% neither involves  any  payment  nor  credit  of  such  sum  by  way  of  cash,  issue  of cheque or draft nor by any other mode. Thus, the deduction of tax at source under section 194C doesn't arise.
